column2: Indicator
column5: dataSource
column7: description
column9: Note

column2: Years of Potential Life Lost Before Age 75
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Years of Potential Life Lost Before Age 75 (YPLL-75) is an age-adjusted rate per 100,000 of the population. It is based on the average years a person would have lived if he or she had not died before age 75.
column9: The methods for calculating premature death have been updated since prior reports, and all data years have been recalculated.

column2: Life Expectancy in Years, Male
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Life expectancy at birth is the expected number of years to be lived by someone born at the time of calculation, if mortality at each age remains constant in the future.

column2: Life Expectancy in Years, Female
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Life expectancy at birth is the expected number of years to be lived by someone born at the time of calculation, if mortality at each age remains constant in the future.

column2: Gap in Life Expectancy at Birth Between Black and White Philadelphians, Male
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: The gap in life expectancy at birth between black, non-Hispanic and white, non-Hispanic Philadelphians. The life expectancy for black is subtracted from the life expectancy for white.

column2: Gap in Life Expectancy at Birth Between Black and White Philadelphians, female
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: The gap in life expectancy at birth between black, non-Hispanic and white, non-Hispanic Philadelphians. The life expectancy for black is subtracted from the life expectancy for white.

column2: Poor or Fair Health
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults who rate their health as "fair" or "poor" in response to the question, "In general, would you say that your health is excellent, very good, good, fair, or poor?"

column2: Adult Smoking Prevalence
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults who have smoked at least 100 cigarettes in their lifetime and currently smoke "every day" or "some days."

column2: Teen Smoking Prevalence, 9th-12th Grade
column5: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
column7: Percentage of 9th-12th grade students who smoked on at least one day in past 30 days.

column2: Smoking-Attributable Mortality Rate per 100,000 People
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Age-adjusted rate of deaths attributable to smoking per 100,000 adults 35 years and older. This measure is based on CDC's [Smoking-Attributable Mortality, Morbidity, and Economic Costs (SAMMEC)] (https://chronicdata.cdc.gov/Health-Consequences-and-Costs/Smoking-Attributable-Mortality-Morbidity-and-Econo/3kjq-j5dm/data) methodology. For more details: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK294316/.
column9: The methods for calculating premature death have been updated since prior reports, and all data years have been recalculated.

column2: Secondhand Smoke Exposure at Home Among Children
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of children under 18 who live with an adult who smokes in the home.

column2: Adult Binge Drinking
column5: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS)
column7: Percentage of adults reporting binge drinking.
column9: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention definte binge drinking as drinking 5 or more drinks on an occasion for men or 4 or more drinks on an occasion for women. Binge drinking is no longer being tracked separately and will be combined with heavy drinking beginning in 2014. Please note that data years differ across dimensions for this indicator.

column2: Adult Excessive Drinking
column5: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) as reported by County Health Rankings & Roadmaps
column7: Percentage of adults reporting binge or heavy drinking.
column9: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention definte binge drinking as drinking 5 or more drinks on an occasion for men or 4 or more drinks on an occasion for women and heavy drinking as drinking 15 or more drinks per week for men, or 8 or more drinks per week for women. Binge drinking is no longer being tracked separately and will be combined with heavy drinking beginning in 2014. Please note that data years differ across dimensions for this indicator.

column2: Teen Binge Drinking, 9th-12th Grade
column5: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
column7: Percentage of 9th-12th grade students who had 5 or more alcoholic drinks in a row within a couple hours on at least one day in past 30 days.
column9: Data is not available for 2005.

column2: Child Obesity Prevalence, 5-18 Years of Age
column5: School District of Philadelphia
column7: Percentage of children, age 5 to 18 years, enrolled in the School District of Philadelphia (SDP) with a body mass index (BMI) greater than or equal to the 95th percentile for their age and gender group based on 2000 Centers for Disease Control growth charts. BMI data are based on nurse-measured heights and weights.
column9: Data are by school year. For example, 2005 refers to the school year spanning fall 2004 and spring 2005.

column2: Adult Obesity Prevalence
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults with BMI greater than or equal to 30kg/m2, based on self-reported height and weight.

column2: Adults Drinking ≥ 1 Sugary Drink Daily
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults who drank soda, sweetened fruit drinks, and/or bottled teas at least once a day for past 30 days. Respondents were instructed “do not include diet soda/drinks.”

column2: Teens Drinking ≥ 1 Soda Daily, 9th-12th Grade
column5: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
column7: Percentage of 9th-12th grade students who drank soda at least once a day for past 30 days. Respondents were instructed “Do not count diet soda or diet pop.”
column9: Examples provided to respondents included Coke, Pepsi, and Sprite.

column2: Premature Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) Mortality Rate per 100,000 People
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Age-adjusted rate per 100,000 persons of CVD deaths to persons under 65 years of age.

column2: Adult Hypertension Prevalence
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults who have been told by a doctor or other health professional that they have high blood pressure or hypertension. Excludes respondents with a history of gestational hypertension only.

column2: Adult Diabetes Prevalence
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults who have been told by a doctor or other health professional that they have or have had diabetes. Excludes respondents with a history of gestational diabetes only.

column2: New HIV Diagnoses per 100,000 People
column5: AIDS Activities Coordinating Office, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Rate of new HIV diagnoses per 100,000 of the population.

column2: New HIV Diagnoses from Male-to-Male Sexual Contact
column5: AIDS Activities Coordinating Office, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Count of new HIV diagnoses from male-to-male sexual contact.

column2: New HIV Diagnoses from Heterosexual Contact
column5: AIDS Activities Coordinating Office, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Count of new HIV diagnoses from heterosexual contact.
column9: Data not available for Heterosexual Contact for 2009.

column2: New HIV Diagnoses from Injection Drug Use
column5: AIDS Activities Coordinating Office, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Count of new HIV diagnoses from injection drug use.

column2: Retention in HIV/AIDS Care
column5: AIDS Activities Coordinating Office, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Percentage of persons living with diagnosed HIV having had 2 or more CD4 or viral load test results, at least 3 months apart, during a 12 month period.

column2: Viral Suppression
column5: AIDS Activities Coordinating Office, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Percentage of persons diagnosed living with HIV, who were alive at year end and had a viral load < 200 at most recent test. Persons diagnosed living with HIV whose viral load was not assessed were considered unsuppressed.

column2: Adults Never Tested for HIV, 18-39 Years of Age
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults, age 18-39 years old, reporting "never" to the question, "The next question is about the test for HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. About how long has it been since you last had a test for HIV? Would you say one year or less, more than one year, up to two years, more than 2 years, or never?"

column2: Teens Who Are Currently Sexually Active, 9th-12th Grade
column5: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
column7: Percentage of 9th-12th grade students who reported having had sexual intercourse during the past 3 months.
column9: Data are not available for 2005.

column2: Teens Who Used Condom with Last Sexual Encounter, 9th-12th Grade
column5: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
column7: Percentage of sexually active 9th-12th grade students who reported using a condom during the most recent sexual intercourse. Respondents are considered sexually active if they report intercourse with at least one person in the three months preceding the survey.
column9: Data are not available for 2005.

column2: Teens Who Used Birth Control with Last Sexual Encounter, 9th-12th Grade
column5: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
column7: Percentage of sexually active 9th-12th grade students who used some form of birth control during the most recent sexual intercourse. Respondents are considered sexually active if they report intercourse with at least one person in the three months preceding the survey.
column9: Data are not available for 2005.

column2: Teen Births per 1,000 Teen Girls, 15-19 Years of Age
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Birth rate per 1,000 teen girls age 15-19 years.

column2: Teen Chlamydia Rate per 100,000 Teens, 15-19 Years of Age
column5: Division of Disease Control, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Diagnosed chlamydia infection rate per 100,000 teens age 15-19 years.

column2: Teen Gonorrhea Rate per 100,000 Teens, 15-19 Years of Age
column5: Division of Disease Control, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Diagnosed gonorrhea infection rate per 100,000 teens age 15-19 years.

column2: Infant Mortality Rate per 1,000 Live Births
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Mortality rate per 1,000 live-born infants under one year of age.

column2: Low Birth Weight Births
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Percentage of live-born infants weighing less than 2,500 grams - or 5 pounds 8 ounces - at birth.

column2: Late or No Prenatal Care
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Percentage of women who received prenatal care either in the third trimester or not at all, out of all women giving birth within the year, for whom the timing of prenatal care is known.

column2: Breastfeeding Initiation
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Percentage of women initiating breastfeeding before hospital discharge, out of all women for whom breastfeeding status is known.
column9: The methods for calculating breastfeeding initiation have been updated since prior reports, and all data years have been recalculated.

column2: Children Up to Date on Immunizations, 19-35 Months of Age
column5: Division of Disease Control, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Percentage of children, age 19-35 months, who have completed the recommended vaccination schedule 4:3:1:3 (DTaP : IPV : MMR : Hib).

column2: Asthma Hospitalization Rate per 10,000 Children, < 18 Years of Age
column5: Pennsylvania Health Care Cost Containment Council
column7: Age-adjusted rate of hospital discharges with a primary diagnosis of asthma per 100,000 children under 18 years of age.
column9: The methods for calculating asthma hospitalization have been updated since prior reports, and all data years have been recalculated.

column2: Newly Identified Elevated Blood Lead Levels (5-9 mcg/dL) in Children, < 6 Years of Age
column5: Pennsylvania's National Electronic Disease Surveillance System (PA-NEDSS), as reported by Environmental Health Services, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Percentage of children, 0-5 years old, with newly identified blood lead levels (BLLs) from 5-9 mcg/dL using any blood specimens for screening.

column2: Newly Identified Elevated Blood Lead Levels (10+ mcg/dL) in Children, < 6 Years of Age
column5: Pennsylvania's National Electronic Disease Surveillance System (PA-NEDSS), as reported by Environmental Health Services, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Percentage of children, 0-5 years old, with newly identified blood lead levels (BLLs) at or above 10 mcg/dL using any blood specimens for screening.

column2: Pedestrian and Bicycle Crashes per 100,000 Children, < 18 Years of Age
column5: Pennsylvania Department of Transportation
column7: Rate of pedestrian and bicyclist crashes involving motor vehicles per 100,000 children under 18.

column2: Child Mortality Rate per 100,000 Children, < 18 Years of Age
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Age-adjusted mortality rate per 100,000 children under 18 years of age.
column9: See PDPH Vital Statistics Reports for causes of death by age: http://www.phila.gov/health/commissioner/VitalStatistics.html

column2: Adults Without Insurance, 18-64 Years of Age
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults, age 18-64 years old, reporting no source of insurance.

column2: Children Without Insurance, < 18 Years of Age
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of children under 18 for whom no source of insurance is reported by adult proxy.

column2: Adults Covered by Medicaid, 18-64 Years of Age
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults, age 18-64 years, reporting insurance coverage through Medicaid, Medical Assistance (M.A.), HealthChoices, or Access Card.

column2: Adults Forgoing Care Due to Cost, 18-64 Years of Age
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults, age 18-64 years, answering "yes" to the question, "In the past year, has there been any time when you were sick or injured AND did not seek health care because of the cost?"

column2: Ambulatory Care Sensitive Hospitalization Rate per 100,000 People, < 75 Years of Age
column5: Pennsylvania Health Care Cost Containment Council
column7: Age-adjusted rate per 100,000 persons for conditions where appropriate ambulatory care prevents or reduces the need for admission to the hospital, for population under 75 years of age.
column9: The methods for calculating ambulatory care sensitive hospitalizations have been updated since prior reports, and all data years have been recalculated.

column2: Children with Dental Visit in Past Year, 3-17 Years of Age
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of children, age 3-17 years, for whom adult proxy reported dental visit in past 12 months.

column2: Cancer Mortality per 100,000 People
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Age-adjusted rate of cancer deaths per 100,000 persons.

column2: Adults with Colonoscopy or Sigmoidoscopy in Lifetime, 50-74 Years of Age
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults, age 50-74 years, reporting ever having had a colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy.

column2: Women with Mammography in Past 2 Years, 50-74 Years of Age
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of women, age 50-74 years, reporting having had a mammogram in the past 2 years.

column2: Girls Completing 3-Dose HPV Vaccine, 13-17 Years of Age
column5: Division of Disease Control, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Percentage of girls, age 13-17 years, who received 3 doses of HPV vaccine out of all girls 13-17 years in the population.
column9: Data are based on local reporting of immunizations provided by clinicians, and some underreporting for adolescents may occur.

column2: Food Establishments in Compliance with Food Safety Regulations Upon Initial Annual Inspection
column5: Environmental Health Services, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Percentage of food establishments in compliance with food safety regulations upon initial annual inspection by the Philadelphia Department of Public Health.
column9: Data are by fiscal year.

column2: Rat Complaints per 10,000 People
column5: Environmental Health Services, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Rate of rat complaint calls to the Philadelphia Department of Public Health per 10,000 residents.
column9: The methods for calculating rat complaints per 10,000 people have been updated slightly since prior reports, and all data years have been recalculated.

column2: Days with Good Air Quality
column5: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) AMP410S report dated 6/28/16, as reported by Air Management Services, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Number of days of the year with Air Quality Index (AQI) levels of 0-50, wherein air quality is considered satisfactory and air pollution poses little or no risk. AQI is a scale from 0 to 500, reflecting measures of ground-level ozone, particulate matter, carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, and nitrogen dioxide.
column9: The reporting is based on 2015 Environmental Protection Agency standards.

column2: Days with Moderate Air Quality
column5: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) AMP410S report dated 6/28/16, as reported by Air Management Services, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Number of days of the year with Air Quality Index (AQI) levels of 51-150, wherein air quality is considered acceptable but may be unhealthy for sensitive groups. AQI is a scale from 0 to 500, reflecting measures of ground-level ozone, particulate matter, carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, and nitrogen dioxide.
column9: The reporting is based on 2015 Environmental Protection Agency standards.

column2: Days with Unhealthy Air Quality
column5: United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) AMP410S report dated 6/28/16, as reported by Air Management Services, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Number of days of the year with Air Quality Index (AQI) levels of 151-500, wherein air quality is considered “unhealthy to sensitive people” to “hazardous”, and everyone may begin to experience some adverse health effects.  AQI is a scale from 0 to 500, reflecting measures of ground-level ozone, particulate matter, carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, and nitrogen dioxide.
column9: The reporting is based on 2015 Environmental Protection Agency standards.

column2: Philadelphia Building Construction and Occupancy Code Violations per 1,000 Occupied Housing Units
column5: City of Philadelphia Licenses and Inspections
column7: Rate of Philadelphia Building Construction and Occupancy Code violations per 1,000 occupied housing units. Violations are based on follow-up inspections to complaints filed through Philly 311.

column2: Violent Crime Rate per 100,000 People
column5: FBI Uniform Crime Reports
column7: Rate per 100,000 persons of reported violent crimes, including murders and non-negligent manslaughters, forcible rapes, robberies, and aggravated assaults.

column2: Homicide Mortality Rate per 100,000 People
column5: Medical Examiner's Office, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Rate of homicide deaths per 100,000 persons.

column2: Firearm Homicide Rate per 100,000 People
column5: Medical Examiner's Office, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Rate of intentional deaths by discharge of firearm per 100,000 persons.

column2: Suicide Mortality Rate per 100,000 People
column5: Vital Statistics for Philadelphia, Pennsylvania Department of Health
column7: Age-adjusted rate of deaths by intentional self-harm per 100,000 persons.

column2: Teens Considering Suicide in Past Year, 9th-12th grade
column5: Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance System
column7: Percentage of 9th-12th grade students who seriously considered attempting suicide in past 12 months.

column2: Adults with Diagnosed Mental Health Condition
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults answering "yes" to the question, "Have you ever been diagnosed with any mental health condition, including clinical depression, anxiety disorder or bipolar disorder?"

column2: Opioid-Related Mortality Rate per 100,000 People
column5: Medical Examiner's Office, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Rate of deaths per 100,000 persons that were determined by the medical examiner to be caused by drug/medication overdose and for which a toxicology test was positive for an opioid.
column9: Opioids include heroin, morphine, methadone, and all prescriptions opioids such as codeine, hydrocodone, and oxycodone.

column2: Low-to-no Walkable Access to Healthy Foods and High Poverty
column5: Get Healthy Philly, Philadelphia Department of Public Health
column7: Percentage of population living in high-poverty areas with low-to-no walkable access to healthy foods as assessed in PDPH's [Food Access Report](http://www.phila.gov/health/pdfs/WalkableAccessHealthyFood20122014.pdf).

column2: Access to Nearby Parks or Outdoor Space
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults responding yes to the question, “Is there a park or other outdoor space in your neighborhood that you’re comfortable visiting during the day?”

column2: Pedestrian and Bicycle Crashes per 100,000 People
column5: Pennsylvania Department of Transportation
column7: Rate of pedestrian and bicyclist crashes involving motor vehicles per 100,000 persons.

column2: Advanced or Proficient Reading Skills in 3rd Grade
column5: School District of Philadelphia
column7: Percentage of 3rd graders who score at the advanced or proficient levels of English Language Arts (ELA) as assessed by the Pennsylvania System of School Assessment (PSSA) standardized test.
column9: Data are by school year. For example, 2005 refers to the school year spanning fall 2004 and spring 2005.

column2: Advanced or Proficient Reading Skills and English Language Arts (ELA) Achievemet in 3rd Grade
column5: School District of Philadelphia
column7: Percentage of 3rd graders who score at the advanced or proficient levels of English Language Arts (ELA) as assessed by the Pennsylvania System of School Assessment (PSSA) standardized test.
column9: Data are by school year. For example, 2005 refers to the school year spanning fall 2004 and spring 2005. This is a new exam, beginning in 2015, so data from prior years is not comparable.

column2: On-Time High School Graduation
column5: School District of Philadelphia as reported by The Notebook
column7: Percentage of all students who graduate from high school within four years after starting 9th grade.
column9: Data are by school year. For example, 2005 refers to the school year spanning fall 2004 and spring 2005.

column2: Adults Completing Some College, ≥ 25 Years of Age
column5: US Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 1-year estimates
column7: Percentage of adults, 25 years or older, who completed at least some college.
column9: Please note that data years differ across dimensions for this indicator.

column2: Unemployment, ≥ 16 Years of Age
column5: Bureau of Labor Statistics, Local Area Unemployment Statistics - Annual Averages (County data)
column7: Percentage of population, 16 years or older, who are unemployed but seeking work.
column9: Please note that data sources and years differ across dimensions for this indicator.

column2: Philadelphians Living in Poverty
column5: US Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 1-year estimates
column7: Percentage of population, including all ages, living in a household with an income below 100% of the federal poverty level (FPL).
column9: In 2015, the FPL was equivalent to a yearly income of no more than $11,770 for an individual, or $24,250 for a family of 4. Please note that data years differ across dimensions for this indicator.

column2: Children Living in Poverty, < 18 Years of Age
column5: US Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 1-year estimates
column7: Percentage of children under 18 with a family income below 100% of the federal poverty level (FPL).
column9: In 2015, the FPL was equivalent to a yearly income of no more than $11,770 for an individual, or $24,250 for a family of 4. Please note that data years differ across dimensions for this indicator.

column2: Children in Single-Parent Households, < 18 Years of Age
column5: US Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 1-year estimates
column7: Percentage of all children in family households that live in a household headed by a single parent (male or female head of household with no spouse present).

column2: Social Capital
column5: Public Health Management Corporation (PHMC) Household Health Survey
column7: Percentage of adults reporting "yes" to, "Have people in your neighborhood ever worked together to improve the neighborhood? For example, through a neighborhood watch, creating a community garden, building a community playground, or participating in a block party."

column2: Housing-Cost Burden for Renters
column5: US Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 1-year estimates
column7: Percentage of the household population who pays 30% or more of their income for rental housing.
column9: According to the US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), families who pay more than 30% of their income for housing are considered cost burdened and may have difficulty affording necessities such as food, clothing, transportation, and medical care.
